title: The new Trek RSL Knit shoes are as expensive as they look
content:
Cyclist
The new Trek RSL Knit shoes are as expensive as they look

Trek has launched three new shoe designs. Its pro-spec RSL Knit shoes, as you’d guess, have a knitted upper. They’re available in white and silver, if black and gold is a bit too bling for you.

The RSL Road shoes share many of the RSL Knit’s features but have a more standard TPU upper and black or white colour options. There’s also an update of the Velocis shoes, which move to the Trek label.

The UK price for the Trek RSL Knit shoes is £399.99, while the RSL Pro shoes cost £349.99. The price of the Velocis shoes is a little more affordable at £229.99.

New pro last and new features

RSL stands or Race Shop Limited and denotes Trek’s top spec kit. All three new shoes feature the same last, which Trek says will fit better on a wider range of riders’ feet and incorporate zones designed to stretch for greater comfort.

While Trek has previously marketed its shoes under the Bontrager name, the new shoes mark a change to labelling them Trek. It had recently done the same with its latest helmets. Does this mark a retreat from the Bontrager brand, which it previously used for its components and accessories, or will Bontrager be redirected to Trek’s hardware or its less premium lines? 

Trek RSL Knit shoes

We spotted the Trek RSL Knit shoes (in white) on the feet of Mads Pedersen at the Lidl-Trek team’s recent training camp. Now Trek has officially launched the new shoes, which come in a white/silver or the seriously bling (until you scuff the soles) black/gold colour option.

The new shoes feature what Trek calls Metnet relief zones, which it claims stretch with the foot to help relieve foot discomfort. They sit within reinforced areas around the twin Boa dials, with Trek stating that the variable densities to the knitted polyester fabric provide both performance and comfort. The brand claims that the uppers offer high breathability for better foot temperature management than a traditional upper.

The shoe’s last is an update on the Bontrager InForm Pro last, which Trek says improves the fit for the shape and width of Joe Average’s foot. There’s an integral sock liner and an insole made from a naturally derived, part-recycled fabric.

Closure uses two Boa Li2 dials with bidirectional tension adjustment, which are becoming the de facto standard on top spec cycling shoes. They also feature on the just-released update to the Specialized Torch 3.0 shoes. Trek says that its shoes’ heel cup is designed for improved hold on the heel and better pedalling efficiency. 

On the bottom, Trek has a carbon sole that it rates 14/14 on its stiffness index. The new insole is made from a natural-based foam, replacing the more common synthetic EVA foam.

Trek RSL Road shoes

If you prefer a more standard TPU upper, the Trek RSL shoes are also used by the Lidl-Trek pros and feature the same last as the RSL Knit. They too include two Boa Li2 dial closures, a heel cup with a non-slip lining and the same Rise by Bloom natural foam liner as the Trek RSL Knit shoes.

There are also the same Metnet relief zones built into the uppers to add extra stretch, while the front of the uppers and the tongue are perforated for ventilation. There are another four vents in the carbon sole, which again is rated 14/14 for stiffness by Trek. Colours available are black (without the gold accents, sorry) or white.

Updated Trek Velocis shoes

With this latest update, Trek has rebranded its Velocis shoes under its own name, rather than using the Bontrager brand.

The Trek Velocis shoes have a PU upper with the same InForm Pro last as the shoes above. They too feature Metnet relief zones to increase foot comfort, forefoot and tongue venting and two Boa Li2. They get a slightly less stiff carbon/fibreglass composite sole with two vents, which Trek rates 12/14 on its stiffness index. They’re available in black, white and red.

Sizing and pricing for the new range

The Trek RSL Knit shoes are priced at £399.99 in the UK, $499.99 in the US and €449.99 in the EU. Claimed weight is 225g for a size 42 shoe.

The RSL Road shoes cost £349.99 / $449.99 / €399.99 and also have a claimed weight of 225g per shoe in size 42. 

The Velocis shoes are priced at £229.99 / $249.99 / €249.99, with a claimed weight of 222g per shoe, again for a size 42. 

All Trek’s new shoes are available in sizes from 36 to 48, with half sizes between 38.5 and 45.5.

You can buy the Trek Biodynamic insoles for all three shoes separately, priced at £26.99 / €29.99.

All Trek’s shoes come with a 30-day unconditional guarantee, which offers a full refund if you don’t get on with them, and are warrantied for two years.

The post The new Trek RSL Knit shoes are as expensive as they look appeared first on Cyclist.
author: pnorman
